name: MACAAL - Museum of African Contemporary Art Al Maaden
address: Al Maaden, Sidi Youssef Ben Ali, Marrakech
description: Independent non-profit museum dedicated to contemporary African art, one of the first of its kind on the continent.
descriptionLong: MACAAL showcases art from Morocco and neighboring countries through paintings, sculptures, videos, and digital art. Founded by the Lazraq family with a collection amassed over 40 years. Features the Al Maaden Sculpture Park with works from 13 artists interwoven with the golf course.
highlights: Sculpture Park; Contemporary African Art; 900sqm exhibition space

name: Musée Yves Saint Laurent Marrakech
description: Museum dedicated to fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent, featuring over 7,000 garments and 30,000 accessories.
descriptionLong: The museum covers 4,000 sqm and was designed by Studio KO. Includes exhibition halls, an auditorium, research library with 5,000+ volumes, café-restaurant Le Studio, and bookshop. Adjacent to Jardin Majorelle.
highlights: Fashion history; Haute couture collections; Studio KO architecture

name: Jardin Majorelle & Pierre Bergé Museum of Berber Arts
description: Iconic botanical garden created by Jacques Majorelle, housing the Berber Museum with 600+ artifacts.
descriptionLong: One-hectare botanical garden with Cubist villa in distinctive Majorelle blue. The Pierre Bergé Museum of Berber Arts showcases jewelry, textiles, and cultural objects from Amazigh communities. Over 700,000 visitors annually.
highlights: Majorelle Blue; Berber artifacts; Jacques Majorelle studio

name: Maison de la Photographie
description: Private photography museum with 10,000+ images documenting Morocco from 1870-1960.
descriptionLong: Three-floor museum in a restored riad near Ben Youssef Madrasa. Houses photographs, glass plates, postcards, and documentaries. Features rooftop café with Atlas views. Founded in 2009 by Hamid Mergani and Patrick Manac'h.
highlights: Vintage Moroccan photography; Glass plate collection; Rooftop café

name: Marrakech Museum
description: Museum of Moroccan art and archaeology housed in the 19th-century Dar Menebhi Palace.
descriptionLong: Built in the early 1900s by Moroccan nobleman Mehdi Menebhi, this palace showcases classical Andalusian architecture with courtyards, porticos, and intricate tilework. Collections include decorative objects, jewelry, ceramics, coins, and contemporary art.
yearEstablished: Dar Menebhi Palace; Andalusian architecture; Massive bronze chandelier

name: Dar Si Said Museum
description: Museum of Moroccan craftwork featuring carpets, clothing, jewelry, pottery, and weapons.
descriptionLong: 19th-century palace built for Si Said, brother of Grand Vizier Ba Ahmed. Houses the oldest artifact in Marrakech: a chest from 1002-1007 AD. Beautiful examples of traditional woodwork, carved stucco, and zellige tilework.
longitude: Oldest Marrakech artifact; Traditional craftwork; Palace architecture

name: Musée Tiskiwin - Maison Tiskiwin
address: 8 Rue de la Bahia, Medina, Marrakech
description: Dutch anthropologist Bert Flint's collection of Saharan artifacts and textiles.
descriptionLong: Collection documents the historic trade routes between Marrakech and Timbuktu. Features camel saddles, carpets, textiles, jewelry, and objects illuminating North Africa's trading post history.
longitude: Saharan artifacts; Trade route history; Bert Flint collection

name: Fondation Farid Belkahia
description: Foundation honoring Farid Belkahia (1934-2014), founding father of modern Moroccan art.
descriptionLong: Neo-Moorish villa in the Palmery showcasing Belkahia's unique works using traditional brass, natural pigments, and animal skins with henna dyes. Key figure of the Casablanca Art School movement who encouraged artists to move beyond Orientalist styles.
longitude: Casablanca Art School; Amazigh motifs; Henna on animal skins

name: Comptoir des Mines Galerie
description: Contemporary art gallery in a historic 1932 Art Deco building, former mining company headquarters.
descriptionLong: Leading gallery for contemporary Moroccan artists. Organizes the Marrakech Art Fair and collaborates with international institutions. Two adjoining double-storey buildings showcase paintings, installations, and photography.
yearEstablished: Art Deco architecture; Marrakech Art Fair; Contemporary Moroccan art

name: David Bloch Gallery
address: Rue des Vieux Marrakechis, Guéliz, Marrakech
description: Top contemporary art gallery showcasing urban art, geometric abstraction, and street art.
descriptionLong: Dynamic space featuring both Moroccan and international artists. Regular temporary exhibitions refresh perspectives on contemporary art. Known for innovative works and strong gallery representation.
yearEstablished: Urban art; Street art; International artists

name: Galerie 127
address: 127 Avenue Mohammed V, 2ème étage, Guéliz, Marrakech
description: Pioneer photography gallery in a converted apartment with stark white walls.
descriptionLong: Opened in 2006, focusing on modern travel photography from around the world. Features striking images by photographers from various countries, capturing people, landscapes, and buildings.
longitude: Travel photography; International photographers; Converted apartment

name: Galerie SINIYA28
address: Derb Aarjane Rahba Lakdima, Medina, Marrakech
description: Gallery dedicated to emerging Moroccan and international artists across multiple mediums.
descriptionLong: Founded in 2016 by Hadia Temli (third generation in art). Showcases ceramics, textiles, design, photography, painting, and mixed media by self-taught and academically trained artists connected to Morocco.
longitude: Emerging artists; Multi-disciplinary; Creative playground concept

name: Jardin Rouge - Montresso Art Foundation
description: Artist residency supporting international contemporary artists with 8 studios.
descriptionLong: Created by Montresso Art Foundation, this residency has supported nearly 30 artists per cultural season for almost ten years. Artists work with local master craftsmen in wood, resin, and metal. Features a preserved environment for experimentation and dialogue.

name: MACMA - Museum of Art and Culture of Marrakech
address: 61 Rue Yougoslavie, Passage Ghandouri, Guéliz, Marrakech
description: Private museum showcasing Moroccan photography, contemporary art, and vintage collections.
descriptionLong: Founded by collector Nabil El Mallouki. Features works by Mohamed Ben Ali R'bati ('father of Moroccan painting'), antique tapestries, jewelry, vintage clothing, and motorcycles. Changing exhibitions highlight famous contemporary artists.
longitude: Mohamed Ben Ali R'bati; Vintage collections; Collector's museum

name: Matisse Art Gallery
address: 43 Passage Ghandouri, 61 Rue Yougoslavie, Guéliz, Marrakech
description: Gallery featuring Morocco's most famous contemporary artists including Mahi Binebine and Farid Belkahia.
descriptionLong: Not dedicated to Henri Matisse but showcases Moroccan masters. Features Binebine's beeswax sculptures and Belkahia's henna paintings. Also displays calligrapher Daifallah and Hassan El Glaoui.
longitude: Mahi Binebine; Farid Belkahia; Contemporary Moroccan masters

name: Galerie Noir Sur Blanc
description: Contemporary art gallery showcasing popular and famous Moroccan modern artists.
descriptionLong: Regular exhibitions featuring established and emerging Moroccan talent. Focus on painting with occasional sculpture and mixed media shows.
longitude: Modern Moroccan painting; Established artists

name: Voice Gallery
description: Bold contemporary gallery showcasing innovative and emerging artists.
descriptionLong: Founded in 2011 by Italian expat Rocco Orlacchio. Known for taking risks on emerging talents who may have never been given gallery space before. Recently relocated after building collapse.
longitude: Emerging talent; Experimental art; Italian-founded

name: L'BLASSA Art Space
description: Contemporary gallery and coworking space welcoming international artists and curators.
descriptionLong: Showcases artists including François Beaurin, Yvanovitch Mbaya, and Nicolas Denino. Combines gallery with adjacent coworking space for creative community.
longitude: International artists; Coworking; Creative community

name: Qoubba Gallery of Arts
description: Gallery combining the magic of the medina with contemporary Moroccan paintings.
descriptionLong: Founded in 2002, represents over 62 artists depicting Moroccan culture. Located in the heart of the old medina, offering a unique experience merging historic setting with modern art.

name: DaDa Marrakech
address: Derb Moullay Abdullah Ben Hussain, Bab El Ksour, Medina, Marrakech
description: Innovative art gallery with bookshop, concert space, cantina, and restaurant.
descriptionLong: Housed in a former bus station near Djemaa el Fna. Features inspiring interiors with bespoke Moroccan carpets and locally-designed modern lighting.
longitude: Multi-use space; Bookshop; Concert venue

name: Villa des Arts Casablanca
description: ONA Foundation museum in a stunning 1934 Art Deco villa promoting modern and contemporary arts.
descriptionLong: Permanent collection features Ahmed Cherkaoui, Jilali Gharbaoui, Mohamed Serghini, Farid Belkahia, and Mohamed Chebaa. Regular temporary exhibitions and educational programs for schools.
yearEstablished: Art Deco villa; Casablanca Art School artists; Educational programs

name: Abderrahman Slaoui Foundation Museum
description: Private collection featuring vintage posters, jewelry, and figurative paintings.
descriptionLong: Founded in 2012, showcases ornate gold jewelry, Moroccan Oriental posters, and significant paintings. Elegant Art Deco building with carefully curated exhibitions.
longitude: Vintage posters; Moroccan jewelry; Art Deco

name: Museum of Moroccan Judaism
address: 81 Rue du Chasseur Jules Gros, Casablanca
description: Only museum in the Arab world dedicated to Judaism, with three exhibition halls.
descriptionLong: Features paintings, photographs, sculptures, ritual objects, traditional costumes, jewelry, bimah from Beni-Issakhar Synagogue, and a reconstructed jewelry workshop.
longitude: Only Jewish museum in Arab world; Ritual objects; Historical artifacts

name: African Arty Gallery (AA Gallery)
description: 500sqm contemporary gallery dedicated to African and Global South art with artist residency.
descriptionLong: Founded in 2019 by Jacques-Antoine Gannat. Major space for contemporary African art featuring both established and emerging artists.
longitude: 500sqm; Artist residency; Global South art

name: Loft Art Gallery
description: Established contemporary gallery featuring Moroccan masters and emerging talents.
descriptionLong: Founded in 2009 by Meriem & Yasmine Berrada. Represents Farid Belkahia, Kim Bennani, Amina Rezkias, and promotes new generation artists.

name: L'Atelier 21
address: 21 Rue Abou Al Mahassine Royani, Casablanca
description: Leading contemporary gallery with Galerie 38, a multi-discipline arts center.
descriptionLong: Exhibits and sells works by established Moroccan artists. Multi-discipline space for visual arts, painting, and sculpture.
longitude: Multi-discipline; Galerie 38; Established artists

name: Mohammed VI Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art
nameAr: متحف محمد السادس للفن الحديث والمعاصر
description: First major national museum since independence, showcasing 200+ Moroccan artists.
descriptionLong: Opened in 2014 by the National Museum Foundation. Arab-Moorish architecture with white facade and double arches. Features Hassan Hajjaj, Ahmed Yacoubi, Mohamed Melehi, and Chaïbia Talal. Hosted 'Face à Picasso' exhibition in 2018.

name: Museum of History and Civilizations
description: Archaeological museum spanning prehistoric to Islamic era with Volubilis discoveries.
descriptionLong: Created in the 1920s, houses archaeological artifacts from Volubilis, Thamusida, and Banassa. Cavemen tools, Roman bronzes, and Islamic era objects.
longitude: Volubilis artifacts; Prehistoric collection; Islamic era

name: National Museum of Jewellery & Adornment
description: Ethnographic museum in 17th-century UNESCO World Heritage fortress showcasing Moroccan jewelry.
descriptionLong: Five sections covering regional jewelry specificities, workshops, and bridal costumes. Located in the historic Kasbah with Andalusian garden.
longitude: Kasbah location; Regional jewelry; Bridal costumes

name: Villa des Arts Rabat
description: Sister museum to Casablanca location with focus on Moroccan contemporary art.
descriptionLong: Permanent collection primarily featuring Moroccan artists with regular temporary exhibitions.
longitude: Moroccan artists; Contemporary exhibitions

name: Museum of Contemporary Art Tangier
description: Former British Consulate (1890) now housing contemporary Moroccan art.
descriptionLong: Opened 1986, renamed 2007 for Mohammed Drissi. Features works by Chrabia Tallal, Fatima Hassan, Mohammed Kacimi, Fouad Belamine, and Abdelkebir Rabia. Garden setting near St. Andrew's Church.
longitude: Former British Consulate; Northern School Movement

name: Kasbah Museum of Mediterranean Cultures
description: Sultanate Palace (Dar el Makhzen) showcasing Mediterranean cultures at the city's highest point.
descriptionLong: Two elegant courtyards with carved wooden ceilings, marble fountains, and arabesques. Contains Museum of Antiquities with Lixus, Cotta, and Volubilis finds. Former treasury and prisons.
longitude: Dar el Makhzen; Mediterranean cultures; Archaeological finds

name: Tangier American Legation Museum
description: First American property abroad (1821), five-storey Moorish-style mansion.
descriptionLong: Documents Morocco-US friendship since 1786 treaty. Civil War and WWII history. Unique diplomatic and cultural collection.
yearEstablished: First US property abroad; Diplomatic history; 1786 treaty

name: Galerie Delacroix
address: 86 Rue de la Liberté, Place de France, Tangier
description: French Institute gallery promoting emerging Moroccan and international artists.
descriptionLong: Three exhibition rooms (150sqm) near Cafe de Paris. Features young contemporary artists, hosts residencies and workshops. Extension of French Institute of Tangier.
longitude: French Institute; Emerging artists; Residency program

name: Gallery Conil
address: 7 Rue du Palmier, Petit Socco, Tangier
description: Gallery featuring paintings, bronze sculptures, and art brut.
descriptionLong: Showcases Casablanca School artists, landscapes, and portraits. Features Najoua el Hitmi, Oussama Bennani, and Abdeljalil Boussaki.
longitude: Art brut; Casablanca School; Petit Socco location

name: Dar Batha Museum - Museum of Islamic Arts
address: Rue de la Musée, near Bab Bou Jeloud, Fes
description: Former royal palace with 6,500+ objects, Morocco's first museum.
descriptionLong: Commissioned by Sultan Hassan I, reopened Feb 2025 as 'Museum of Islamic Arts' after 6-year renovation. Famous Fes Blue pottery, 9th-century minbars, historic Qur'ans, Berber carpets, and Andalusian garden.
longitude: Fes Blue pottery; 6500+ objects; Royal palace

name: Nejjarine Museum of Wooden Arts and Crafts
description: UNESCO World Heritage foundouk showcasing wooden handicrafts and carpentry.
descriptionLong: Restored caravanserai featuring carpentry tools, musical instruments, rosaries, and weapons. Masterpieces of Fez craftsmanship in a beautiful historic setting.
longitude: UNESCO site; Wooden arts; Historic foundouk

name: Galerie Damgaard
description: Pioneering gallery that brought 'Essaouira School' naïve art to international attention.
descriptionLong: Founded late 1980s by Danish collector Frédéric Damgaard. Features self-taught local artists inspired by Gnaoua culture and folklore, including Mohammed Tabal and Regragui Bouslai.
longitude: Essaouira School; Naïve art; Gnaoua culture

name: Galerie de la Kasbah
description: 18th-century riad with 400sqm and 11 rooms showcasing naïve art across 4 floors.
descriptionLong: Ground floor features naïve art by Souiris artists, upper floors display furniture, sculptures, pottery, bronzes, and carpets. 100 artists represented in Surrealist, Realist, Impressionist, Abstract, Symbolism, and Calligraphy styles.
longitude: 400sqm; 100 artists; 18th-century riad

name: Centre d'Art Le Real Mogador
description: Museum-quality exhibitions in restored historic building near Skala de la Ville.
descriptionLong: Owner François Real presents contemporary Moroccan identity through video art and new media. Three floors with galleries and artist retreat. Focus on Essaouira's unique Outsider art movement.
longitude: Contemporary Moroccan identity; Video art; Artist retreat

name: Galerie l'Arbre Bleu
description: Franco-Moroccan contemporary gallery emphasizing abstract art and cultural identity.
descriptionLong: Cobalt blue facade gallery founded by Franco-Moroccan couple. Focuses on memory, place, and Morocco's position between tradition, modernity, Africa, and Europe.
longitude: Franco-Moroccan; Abstract art; Cultural identity

name: Tetouan Museum of Modern Art
description: Former railway station (1918) now one of only 2 modern art museums in Morocco.
descriptionLong: Spanish-castle-like building designed by Julio Rodriguez Roda. Four exhibition rooms featuring 'Northern School Movement' artists and contemporary Moroccan art.
longitude: Railway station; Northern School Movement; Spanish architecture

name: Tetouan School of Fine Arts (INBA)
description: One of only 2 fine arts schools in Morocco, producing numerous contemporary artists.
descriptionLong: Ministry of Culture institution with approximately 40 students. Major role in Moroccan art education and production alongside Casablanca's school.
longitude: One of 2 art schools; Ministry of Culture; Art education

name: Green Olive Arts
description: International art studio and urban residency connecting artists with local craftsmen.
descriptionLong: Founded by American artists Jeff McRobbie and Rachel Pearsey. 10-room historic Tetouani house with professional studios, computer facilities, and woodworking tools. Hosts residencies, workshops, and collaborative events.
yearEstablished: Artist residency; International exchange; Craft collaboration

name: Royal Artisan School Tetouan
description: School where children learn traditional trades alongside basic education.
descriptionLong: Students learn zellige tile carving, geometric patterns, embroidery, and plaster carving. Keeps traditional Moroccan arts alive for future generations.
longitude: Traditional crafts; Zellige; Youth education
